oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Harold Bradley Interview Tape One Side One
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Guitarist Harold Bradley recalls the career of Patsy Cline from his perspective as a session guitarist on many of her recordings. Discussion includes Patsy Cline's early career development; working in the recording studio with her; his impressions of Cline as a person and as a singer; the material she recorded; her working relationship with producer Owen Bradley; and the arrangement for "Crazy." -- Access Restricted --
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Harold Bradley;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Side One, Tape 1 of 1 (0:00) -- John Rumble introduction of Harold Bradley. Interview being done for the Country Music Foundation Oral History Program, targeted towards the Foundation's multi-CD anthology in tribute to the late Patsy Cline. (0:43) -- John Rumble asks Harold Bradley whether he remembers the first time he met Patsy Cline. Harold Bradley recalls Owen Bradley's work with Patsy Cline on 4 Star Records for Bill McCall. Bill McCall wanted Patsy Cline to record songs that he had the publishing rights to. (2:16) -- John Rumble asks what the main reason was that Patsy Cline had difficulty finding hit songs on 4 Star Records, whether it was the given material, arrangements, or her personal growth as an artist. (3:30) -- Harold Bradley emphasizes the importance of stories within country music songs. (4:33) -- John Rumble asks about whether country music radio struggling and the success of rockabilly held Patsy Cline back. (5:48) -- John Rumble asks about the early 4 Star sessions
